intro: Lerchia obtusifolia, commonly known as the broad-leaved lerchia, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, commonly known as the carrot or parsley family, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbrella-like inflorescences, typical of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine environments. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
